1. creating a link in the startup folder  
    Startup folder is a well-known Windows autostart location.  
    T1547 Boot or Logon Autostart Execution.

2. adding an entry to the registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run  
    Direct modification of the Run key to ensure execution at log-on.  
    T1547 (again, same technique).

3. utilizes malicious Google Chrome extensions  
    Explicit installation of a malicious browser extension.  
    T1176 Browser Extensions.

4. monitors browser activity for online banking actions  
    Actively watches what the user does inside the browser.  
    T1185 Browser Session Hijacking.

5. displaying full-screen overlays to block user access  
    Overlays are used to capture credentials the victim types.  
    T1056 Input Capture.

6. capture and replace Bitcoin wallet addresses in the clipboard  
    Reads and alters clipboard contents.  
    T1115 Clipboard Data.

7. dropper uses VBS files to install and execute its payloads.  
    VBS is executed as a scripting interpreter to run the malware.  
    T1059 Command and Scripting Interpreter.

8. steals credentials from mail clients using NirSoft MailPassView  
    Credential-dumping utility run against the local password store.  
    T1555 Credentials from Password Stores.

9. steals  from Google Chrome.  
    Chromes saved logins are another password store.  
    T1555 (again).

10. decrypts its encrypted configuration files.  
     Encrypted content is decoded at run-time.  
     T1140 Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information.

11. includes a copy of the OpenSSL library to encrypt its C2 traffic  
     Uses a standard cryptographic library to protect C2 communications.  
     T1573 Encrypted Channel.

12. sends collected financial data to its C2 server.  
     Exfiltrates stolen data through the same channel used for command & control.  
     T1041 Exfiltration Over C2 Channel.

Main technique IDs only (no sub-techniques):  
T1547,T1176,T1185,T1056,T1115,T1059,T1555,T1140,T1573,T1041

metadata.description: Mispadu is a banking trojan written in Delphi, first observed in 2019, that operates under a Malware-as-a-Service (MaaS) model. Managed and sold by the Malteiro cybercriminal group, Mispadu primarily targets victims in Brazil and Mexico, with confirmed operations across Latin America and Europe. Mispadu establishes persistence by creating a link in the startup folder and adding an entry to the registry key `HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run`. It utilizes malicious Google Chrome extensions to steal financial data and monitors browser activity for online banking actions, often displaying full-screen overlays to block user access to legitimate sites or to prompt for additional data. The trojan can capture and replace Bitcoin wallet addresses in the clipboard on compromised hosts. Mispadus dropper uses VBS files to install and execute its payloads. Additionally, the malware steals credentials from mail clients using NirSoft MailPassView and from Google Chrome. Before execution, Mispadu decrypts its encrypted configuration files. Mispadu includes a copy of the OpenSSL library to encrypt its command and control (C2) traffic, and it sends collected financial data to its C2 server.

samples.input: Extract all MITRE Enterprise attack patterns from the following text and map them to their corresponding MITRE technique IDs. Provide reasoning for each identification. Ensure the final line contains only the IDs for the main techniques, separated by commas, excluding any subtechnique IDs. MITRE Enterprise IDs are given below as reference.  **Text:** WIREFIRE is a web shell written in Python that exists as trojanized logic to the visits.py component of Ivanti Connect Secure VPN appliances. WIREFIRE was used during Cutting Edge for downloading files and command execution. WIREFIRE can respond to specific HTTP POST requests to /api/v1/cav/client/visits. WIREFIRE can modify the visits.py component of Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs for file download and arbitrary command execution. WIREFIRE can Base64 encode process output sent to C2. WIREFIRE can decode, decrypt, and decompress data received in C2 HTTP POST requests. WIREFIRE can AES encrypt process output sent from compromised devices to C2. WIREFIRE has the ability to download files to compromised devices. WIREFIRE is a web shell that can download files to and execute arbitrary commands from compromised Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs.  **List of All MITRE Enterprise technique IDs** ID    : Name T1548 : 2. T1105  Ingress Tool Transfer  
   The text states WIREFIRE was used  for downloading files and has the ability to download files to compromised devices, which is the classic ingress-tool-transfer behavior.

3. T1059  Command and Scripting Interpreter  
   WIREFIRE can execute arbitrary commands, satisfying the technique for abuse of a command-and-scripting interpreter on the victim host.

4. T1132  Data Encoding  
   WIREFIRE can Base64 encode process output sent to C2 directly corresponds to encoding C2 traffic.

5. T1140  Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information  
   WIREFIRE can decode, decrypt, and decompress data received in C2 HTTP POST requests maps to the de-obfuscation/decoding technique.

6. T1573  Encrypted Channel  
   WIREFIRE can AES encrypt process output sent from compromised devices to C2 shows use of an encrypted C2 channel.

7. T1071.001  Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols  
   Communication occurs via specific HTTP POST requests to /api/v1/cav/client/visits, so the web-protocol sub-technique applies.

Main technique IDs only (no sub-technique IDs):

T1505,T1105,T1059,T1132,T1140,T1573,T1071

samples.input: Extract all MITRE Enterprise attack patterns from the following text and map them to their corresponding MITRE technique IDs. Provide reasoning for each identification. Ensure the final line contains only the IDs for the main techniques, separated by commas, excluding any subtechnique IDs. MITRE Enterprise IDs are given below as reference.  **Text:** LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA is a backdoor that was used by UNC5325 during Cutting Edge to deploy malware on targeted Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs and to establish persistence across system upgrades and patches. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can append malicious components to the tmp/tmpmnt/bin/samba_upgrade.tar archive inside the factory reset partition in attempt to persist post reset. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can initialize itself as a daemon to run persistently in the background. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can communicate over SSL using the private key from the Ivanti Connect Secure web server. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can monitor for system upgrade events by checking for the presence of /tmp/data/root/dev. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can function as a stand-alone backdoor communicating over the /tmp/clientsDownload.sock socket. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA has the ability to function as a SOCKS proxy. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can check the type of Ivanti VPN device it is running on by executing first_run() to identify the first four bytes of the motherboard serial number.  **List of All MITRE Enterprise technique IDs** ID    : Name T1548 : Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism T1134 : Access Token Manipulation T1531 : Account Access Removal T1087 : Account Discovery T1098 : Account Manipulation T1650 : messages.content: Extract all MITRE Enterprise attack patterns from the following text and map them to their corresponding MITRE technique IDs. Provide reasoning for each identification. Ensure the final line contains only the IDs for the main techniques, separated by commas, excluding any subtechnique IDs. MITRE Enterprise IDs are given below as reference.  **Text:** LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA is a backdoor that was used by UNC5325 during Cutting Edge to deploy malware on targeted Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs and to establish persistence across system upgrades and patches. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can append malicious components to the tmp/tmpmnt/bin/samba_upgrade.tar archive inside the factory reset partition in attempt to persist post reset. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can initialize itself as a daemon to run persistently in the background. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can communicate over SSL using the private key from the Ivanti Connect Secure web server. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can monitor for system upgrade events by checking for the presence of /tmp/data/root/dev. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can function as a stand-alone backdoor communicating over the /tmp/clientsDownload.sock socket. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA has the ability to function as a SOCKS proxy. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can check the type of Ivanti VPN device it is running on by executing first_run() to identify the first four bytes of the motherboard serial number.  **List of All MITRE Enterprise Here is a step-by-step mapping of every relevant behavior described in the text to the most appropriate MITRE ATT&CK Enterprise technique, followed by the final comma-separated list of main technique IDs.

1. used by UNC5325 during Cutting Edge to deploy malware on targeted Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs  
    **T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application**  the malware is delivered by exploiting the VPN appliance.

2. establish persistence across system upgrades and patches append malicious components to  samba_upgrade.tar archive inside the factory reset partition  
    **T1542 Pre-OS Boot**  modifying files in the factory-reset partition ensures the implant survives firmware upgrades and factory resets.

3. initialize itself as a daemon to run persistently in the background.  
    **T1543 Create or Modify System Process**  creating a daemon process is a classic way to achieve persistent execution.

4. communicate over SSL using the private key from the Ivanti Connect Secure web server.  
    **T1573 Encrypted Channel**  leveraging the appliances own SSL key to establish an encrypted C2 channel.

5. monitor for system upgrade events by checking for the presence of /tmp/data/root/dev.  
    **T1546 Event Triggered Execution**  the implant waits for an upgrade event (a specific file path) to trigger its next actions.

6. function as a stand-alone backdoor communicating over the /tmp/clientsDownload.sock socket.  
    **T1071 Application Layer Protocol**  using a local Unix domain socket for command-and-control traffic.

7. has the ability to function as a SOCKS proxy.  
    **T1090 Proxy**  providing proxy/tunneling capabilities to route further traffic.

8. check the type of Ivanti VPN device it is running on by executing first_run() to identify the first four bytes of the motherboard serial number.  
    **T1082 System Information Discovery**  gathering hardware/BIOS information to fingerprint the victim device.

Final list of main technique IDs (no sub-techniques):

T1190,T1542,T1543,T1573,T1546,T1071,T1090,T1082

attachments.d50403e8c15044579f5fd7a4fabb3dc9: LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA is a backdoor that was used by UNC5325 during Cutting Edge to deploy malware on targeted Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs and to establish persistence across system upgrades and patches. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can append malicious components to the tmp/tmpmnt/bin/samba_upgrade.tar archive inside the factory reset partition in attempt to persist post reset. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can initialize itself as a daemon to run persistently in the background. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can communicate over SSL using the private key from the Ivanti Connect Secure web server. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can monitor for system upgrade events by checking for the presence of /tmp/data/root/dev. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can function as a stand-alone backdoor communicating over the /tmp/clientsDownload.sock socket. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA has the ability to function as a SOCKS proxy. LITTLELAMB.WOOLTEA can check the type of Ivanti VPN device it is running on by executing first_run() to identify the first four bytes of the motherboard serial number.
attachments.02a657dc51e17a68b0252816d621710e:
Here is a step-by-step mapping of every relevant behavior described in the text to the most appropriate MITRE ATT&CK Enterprise technique, followed by the final comma-separated list of main technique IDs.

1. used by UNC5325 during Cutting Edge to deploy malware on targeted Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs  
    **T1190 Exploit Public-Facing Application**  the malware is delivered by exploiting the VPN appliance.

2. establish persistence across system upgrades and patches append malicious components to  samba_upgrade.tar archive inside the factory reset partition  
    **T1542 Pre-OS Boot**  modifying files in the factory-reset partition ensures the implant survives firmware upgrades and factory resets.

3. initialize itself as a daemon to run persistently in the background.  
    **T1543 Create or Modify System Process**  creating a daemon process is a classic way to achieve persistent execution.

4. communicate over SSL using the private key from the Ivanti Connect Secure web server.  
    **T1573 Encrypted Channel**  leveraging the appliances own SSL key to establish an encrypted C2 channel.

5. monitor for system upgrade events by checking for the presence of /tmp/data/root/dev.  
    **T1546 Event Triggered Execution**  the implant waits for an upgrade event (a specific file path) to trigger its next actions.

6. function as a stand-alone backdoor communicating over the /tmp/clientsDownload.sock socket.  
    **T1071 Application Layer Protocol**  using a local Unix domain socket for command-and-control traffic.

7. has the ability to function as a SOCKS proxy.  
    **T1090 Proxy**  providing proxy/tunneling capabilities to route further traffic.

8. check the type of Ivanti VPN device it is running on by executing first_run() to identify the first four bytes of the motherboard serial number.  
    **T1082 System Information Discovery**  gathering hardware/BIOS information to fingerprint the victim device.

Final list of main technique IDs (no sub-techniques):

T1190,T1542,T1543,T1573,T1546,T1071,T1090,T1082

MITRE Mobile IDs are given below as reference.  **Text:** FlixOnline is an Android malware, first detected in early 2021, believed to target users of WhatsApp. FlixOnline primarily spreads via automatic replies to a devices incoming WhatsApp messages. FlixOnline requests access to the NotificationListenerService, which can allow it to manipulate a device's notifications. FlixOnline may use the BOOT_COMPLETED action to trigger further scripts on boot. FlixOnline can automatically send replies to a users incoming WhatsApp messages. FlixOnline can hide its application icon. FlixOnline requests overlay permissions, which can allow it to create fake Login screens for other apps. Here is the step-by-step mapping of every relevant behavior described in the text to the corresponding MITRE Mobile technique ID, with reasoning for each.

---

### 1. **Automatic replies to incoming WhatsApp messages**
- **Technique ID**: `T1516`  *Input Injection*
- **Reasoning**: The malware automatically sends replies to WhatsApp messages without user interaction. This is a form of injecting input (messages) into the app, which aligns with Input Injection.

---

### 2. **Requests access to NotificationListenerService to manipulate notifications**
- **Technique ID**: `T1517`  *Access Notifications*
- **Reasoning**: NotificationListenerService is explicitly used to access and potentially manipulate notifications. This is a direct match.

---

### 3. **Uses BOOT_COMPLETED action to trigger scripts on boot**
- **Technique ID**: `T1398`  *Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts*
- **Reasoning**: The BOOT_COMPLETED action is used to execute scripts or code at boot time, which is a classic behavior for this technique.

---

### 4. **Automatically sends replies to WhatsApp messages**
- **Technique ID**: `T1516`  *Input Injection*
- **Reasoning**: Already covered above; this is a repeated behavior reinforcing the same technique.

---

### 5. **Hides its application icon**
- **Technique ID**: `T1628`  *Hide Artifacts*
- **Reasoning**: Hiding the app icon is a form of hiding artifacts from the user, which is explicitly covered by this technique.

---

### 6. **Requests overlay permissions to create fake login screens**
- **Technique ID**: `T1655`  *Masquerading*
- **Reasoning**: Overlay permissions are used to create fake UIs (e.g., login screens) that mimic legitimate apps. This is a form of masquerading.

---

### 7. **Steals data from WhatsApp account(s)**
- **Technique ID**: `T1636`  *Protected User Data*
- **Reasoning**: WhatsApp data is considered protected user data. Stealing it directly maps to this technique.

---

### Final Output (Main Technique IDs Only, No Subtechniques):

T1516,T1517,T1398,T1628,T1655,T1636

---

### 2. **Requests access to NotificationListenerService to manipulate notifications**
- **Technique ID**: `T1517`  *Access Notifications*
- **Reasoning**: NotificationListenerService is explicitly used to access and potentially manipulate notifications. This is a direct match.

---

### 3. **Uses BOOT_COMPLETED action to trigger scripts on boot**
- **Technique ID**: `T1398`  *Boot or Logon Initialization Scripts*
- **Reasoning**: The BOOT_COMPLETED action is used to execute scripts or code at boot time, which is a classic behavior for this technique.

---

### 4. **Automatically sends replies to WhatsApp messages**
- **Technique ID**: `T1516`  *Input Injection*
- **Reasoning**: Already covered above; this is a repeated behavior reinforcing the same technique.

---

### 5. **Hides its application icon**
- **Technique ID**: `T1628`  *Hide Artifacts*
- **Reasoning**: Hiding the app icon is a form of hiding artifacts from the user, which is explicitly covered by this technique.

- **Technique ID**: `T1655`  *Masquerading*
- **Reasoning**: Overlay permissions are used to create fake UIs (e.g., login screens) that mimic legitimate apps. This is a form of masquerading.

---

### 7. **Steals data from WhatsApp account(s)**

Lets walk through the text and map every described behavior to the most specific MITRE Enterprise technique that applies.

1. PACEMAKER can enter a loop to read /proc/ entries every 2 seconds in order to read a target application's memory.  
    Continuously reading /proc/<pid>/ to harvest memory contents is classic **OS Credential Dumping** (T1003).

2. PACEMAKER can use a simple bash script for execution.  
    Executing commands or scripts via bash falls under **Command and Scripting Interpreter** (T1059).

3. PACEMAKER has written extracted data to tmp/dsserver-check.statementcounters.  
    Writing collected data to a staging location is **Data Staged** (T1074).

4. PACEMAKER can parse /proc/"process_name"/cmdline to look for the string dswsd within the command line.  
    Examining running processes and their command-line arguments is **Process Discovery** (T1057).

5. PACEMAKER has the ability to extract credentials from OS memory.  
    Again, extracting credentials from memory is **OS Credential Dumping** (T1003).

6. PACEMAKER can use PTRACE to attach to a targeted process to read process memory.  
    Using ptrace to inject into or read another processs memory is **Process Injection** (T1055).

Summary of main technique IDs (excluding sub-techniques):

T1003,T1059,T1074,T1057,T1055

metadata.raw_output:
Lets walk through the text and map every described behavior to the most specific MITRE Enterprise technique that applies.

1. PACEMAKER can enter a loop to read /proc/ entries every 2 seconds in order to read a target application's memory.  
    Continuously reading /proc/<pid>/ to harvest memory contents is classic **OS Credential Dumping** (T1003).

2. PACEMAKER can use a simple bash script for execution.  
    Executing commands or scripts via bash falls under **Command and Scripting Interpreter** (T1059).

3. PACEMAKER has written extracted data to tmp/dsserver-check.statementcounters.  
    Writing collected data to a staging location is **Data Staged** (T1074).

4. PACEMAKER can parse /proc/"process_name"/cmdline to look for the string dswsd within the command line.  
    Examining running processes and their command-line arguments is **Process Discovery** (T1057).

5. PACEMAKER has the ability to extract credentials from OS memory.  
    Again, extracting credentials from memory is **OS Credential Dumping** (T1003).

6. PACEMAKER can use PTRACE to attach to a targeted process to read process memory.  
    Using ptrace to inject into or read another processs memory is **Process Injection** (T1055).

Summary of main technique IDs (excluding sub-techniques):

T1003,T1059,T1074,T1057,T1055

MITRE Enterprise IDs are given below as reference.  **Text:** ZIPLINE is a passive backdoor that was used during Cutting Edge on compromised Secure Connect VPNs for reverse shell and proxy functionality. ZIPLINE can use /bin/sh to create a reverse shell and execute commands. ZIPLINE can use AES-128-CBC to encrypt data for both upload and download. ZIPLINE can find and append specific files on Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs based upon received commands. ZIPLINE can add itself to the exclusion list for the Ivanti Connect Secure Integrity Checker Tool if the --exclude parameter is passed by the tar process. ZIPLINE can download files to be saved on the compromised system. ZIPLINE can communicate with C2 using a custom binary protocol. ZIPLINE can identify running processes and their names. ZIPLINE can create a proxy server on compromised hosts. Here is the step-by-step mapping of every relevant sentence in the text to the most specific MITRE Enterprise technique that is explicitly described.  Only the main technique ID is kept (sub-technique IDs are omitted).

1. used during Cutting Edge on compromised Secure Connect VPNs   
    The VPN appliance was already compromised, so the initial access vector is not described.  No technique mapped.

2. for reverse shell and proxy functionality.  
    Reverse shell  Command and Scripting Interpreter (T1059).  
    Proxy functionality  Proxy (T1090).

3. ZIPLINE can use /bin/sh to create a reverse shell and execute commands.  
    Explicitly using /bin/sh  Command and Scripting Interpreter (T1059).

4. ZIPLINE can use AES-128-CBC to encrypt data for both upload and download.  
    Encrypting C2 traffic  Encrypted Channel (T1573).

5. ZIPLINE can find and append specific files on Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs based upon received commands.  
    Locating files on the host  File and Directory Discovery (T1083).

6. ZIPLINE can add itself to the exclusion list for the Ivanti Connect Secure Integrity Checker Tool   
    Disabling or evading a security tool  Impair Defenses (T1562).

7. ZIPLINE can download files to be saved on the compromised system.  
    Pulling files from C2 to the victim  Ingress Tool Transfer (T1105).

8. ZIPLINE can communicate with C2 using a custom binary protocol.  
    Non-standard C2 protocol  Non-Application Layer Protocol (T1095).

9. ZIPLINE can identify running processes and their names.  
    Listing running processes  Process Discovery (T1057).

10. ZIPLINE can create a proxy server on compromised hosts.  
     Proxy server creation  Proxy (T1090).

11. ZIPLINE can identify a specific string in intercepted network traffic  to trigger its command functionality.  
     Sniffing traffic to trigger actions  Network Sniffing (T1040).

T1059,T1090,T1573,T1083,T1562,T1105,T1095,T1057,T1040

samples.input: Extract all MITRE Enterprise attack patterns from the following text and map them to their corresponding MITRE technique IDs. Provide reasoning for each identification. Ensure the final line contains only the IDs for the main techniques, separated by commas, excluding any subtechnique IDs. MITRE Enterprise IDs are given below as reference.  **Text:** Ninja is a malware developed in C++ that has been used by ToddyCat to penetrate networks and control remote systems since at least 2020. Ninja is possibly part of a post exploitation toolkit exclusively used by ToddyCat and allows multiple operators to work simultaneously on the same machine. Ninja has been used against government and military entities in Europe and Asia and observed in specific infection chains being deployed by Samurai. Ninja can use HTTP for C2 communications. Ninja can create the services httpsvc and w3esvc for persistence. Ninja can encode C2 communications with a base64 algorithm using a custom alphabet. Ninja has the ability to modify headers and URL paths to hide malicious traffic in HTTP requests. Ninja has the ability to mimic legitimate services with customized HTTP URL paths and headers to hide malicious traffic. The Ninja loader component can decrypt and decompress the payload. Ninja can XOR and AES encrypt C2 messages. Ninja can store its final payload in the Registry under $HKLM\SOFTWARE\Classes\Interface\ encrypted with a dynamically generated key based on the drives serial number. Ninja has the ability to enumerate directory content. Ninja loaders can be side-loaded with legitimate and signed executables including the VLC.exe media player. Ninja can change or create the last access or write times.  **List of All MITRE Enterprise technique IDs** ID    : Name T1548 : Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism T1134 : Access Token Manipulation messages.content: Extract all MITRE Enterprise attack patterns from the following text and map them to their corresponding MITRE technique IDs. Provide reasoning for each identification. Ensure the final line contains only the IDs for the main techniques, separated by commas, excluding any subtechnique IDs. MITRE Enterprise IDs are given below as reference.  **Text:** Ninja is a malware developed in C++ that has been used by ToddyCat to penetrate networks and control remote systems since at least 2020. Ninja is possibly part of a post exploitation toolkit exclusively used by ToddyCat and allows multiple operators to work simultaneously on the same machine. Ninja has been used against government and military entities in Europe and Asia and observed in specific infection chains being deployed by Samurai. Ninja can use HTTP for C2 communications. Ninja can create the services httpsvc and w3esvc for persistence. Ninja can encode C2 communications with a base64 algorithm using a custom alphabet. Ninja has the ability to modify headers and URL paths to hide malicious traffic in HTTP requests. Ninja has the ability to mimic legitimate services with customized HTTP URL paths and headers to hide malicious traffic. The Ninja loader component can decrypt and decompress the payload. Ninja can XOR and AES encrypt C2 messages. Ninja can store its final payload in the Registry under $HKLM\SOFTWARE\Classes\Interface\ encrypted with a dynamically generated key based on the drives serial number. Ninja has the ability to enumerate directory content. Ninja loaders can be side-loaded with legitimate and signed executables including the VLC.exe media player. Ninja can change or create the last access or write times.  **List of All MITRE Enterprise technique IDs** ID    : Name T1548 : Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism T1134 : Access Token Manipulation 13. change or create the last access or write times.  
     Indicator Removal: Timestomp (T1070.006)  parent technique T1070.

attachments.153780a1c70f157cb60e86c3cf10cf86: Ninja is a malware developed in C++ that has been used by ToddyCat to penetrate networks and control remote systems since at least 2020. Ninja is possibly part of a post exploitation toolkit exclusively used by ToddyCat and allows multiple operators to work simultaneously on the same machine. Ninja has been used against government and military entities in Europe and Asia and observed in specific infection chains being deployed by Samurai. Ninja can use HTTP for C2 communications. Ninja can create the services httpsvc and w3esvc for persistence. Ninja can encode C2 communications with a base64 algorithm using a custom alphabet. Ninja has the ability to modify headers and URL paths to hide malicious traffic in HTTP requests. Ninja has the ability to mimic legitimate services with customized HTTP URL paths and headers to hide malicious traffic. The Ninja loader component can decrypt and decompress the payload. Ninja can XOR and AES encrypt C2 messages. Ninja can store its final payload in the Registry under $HKLM\SOFTWARE\Classes\Interface\ encrypted with a dynamically generated key based on the drives serial number. Ninja has the ability to enumerate directory content. Ninja loaders can be side-loaded with legitimate and signed executables including the VLC.exe media player. Ninja can change or create the last access or write times.
attachments.1adf2bc9908f63fd947cba8f68cff443:
Here is a line-by-line extraction of every MITRE Enterprise technique that can be confidently inferred from the text, together with the reasoning that links the narrative to the technique.

1. penetrate networks and control remote systems  
    Remote Services (T1021)  the malware is used to reach and operate on remote machines.

2. allows multiple operators to work simultaneously on the same machine.  
    Remote Access Software (T1219)  the description matches a multi-user RAT/back-door console.

3. use HTTP for C2 communications.  
    Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols (T1071.001)  parent technique T1071.

4. create the services httpsvc and w3esvc for persistence.  
    Create or Modify System Process: Windows Service (T1543.003)  parent technique T1543.

5. encode C2 communications with a base64 algorithm using a custom alphabet.  
    Data Encoding: Standard Encoding (T1132.001)  parent technique T1132.

6. modify headers and URL paths to hide malicious traffic  
    Data Obfuscation (T1001)  altering protocol fields to evade detection.

7. mimic legitimate services with customized HTTP URL paths and headers  
    Masquerading (T1036)  traffic is made to look like benign web traffic.

8. loader component can decrypt and decompress the payload.  
    Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information (T1140).

9. XOR and AES encrypt C2 messages.  
    Encrypted Channel: Symmetric Cryptography (T1573.001)  parent technique T1573.

10. store its final payload in the Registry under HKLM\SOFTWARE\Classes\Interface\  
     Modify Registry (T1112).

11. enumerate directory content.  
     File and Directory Discovery (T1083).

12. loaders can be side-loaded with legitimate and signed executables including the VLC.exe media player.  
     Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Side-Loading (T1574.002)  parent technique T1574.

13. change or create the last access or write times.  
     Indicator Removal: Timestomp (T1070.006)  parent technique T1070.

Below is every MITRE Enterprise technique that can be confidently mapped to the description of Samurai, together with the reasoning for each mapping.

1. T1059.003  Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell  
   Reason: Samurai can use a remote command module for execution via the Windows command line.

2. T1055  Process Injection  
   Reason: The loader forces svchost.exe to load the final back-door DLL, which is a form of process injection.

3. T1547.001  Boot or Logon Autostart Execution: Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder  
   Reason: Creating Registry keys under HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\SvcHost to make svchost.exe load the backdoor at boot is a classic Run-key persistence mechanism.

4. T1106  Native API  
   Reason: Samurai has the ability to call Windows APIs.

5. T1071.001  Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols  
   Reason: Samurai uses the .NET HTTPListener class to receive and handle HTTP POST requests for C2.

6. T1132.001  Data Encoding: Standard Encoding  
   Reason: Samurai can base64 encode data sent in C2 communications prior to its encryption.

7. T1573  Encrypted Channel  
   Reason: Samurai can encrypt C2 communications with AES, establishing an encrypted C2 channel.

8. T1041  Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
   Reason: The exfiltration module downloads arbitrary files from compromised machines over the same C2 channel used for command and control.

9. T1083  File and Directory Discovery  
   Reason: Samurai uses a specific module for file enumeration, i.e., discovering files and directories.

10. T1105  Ingress Tool Transfer  
    Reason: Samurai has been used to deploy additional malware (e.g., Ninja) onto compromised hosts.

11. T1574.002  Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Side-Loading  
    Reason: The loader creates directories and Registry keys so that svchost.exe loads attacker-supplied DLLs, a form of DLL side-loading/hijacking.

12. T1112  Modify Registry  
    Reason: Samurai can create multiple Registry keys to force the svchost.exe process to load the final backdoor.

T1059,T1055,T1547,T1106,T1071,T1132,T1573,T1041,T1083,T1105,T1574,T1112

samples.input: Extract all MITRE Enterprise attack patterns from the following text and map them to their corresponding MITRE technique IDs. Provide reasoning for each identification. Ensure the final line contains only the IDs for the main techniques, separated by commas, excluding any subtechnique IDs. MITRE Enterprise IDs are given below as reference.  **Text:** BUSHWALK is a web shell written in Perl that was inserted into the legitimate querymanifest.cgi file on compromised Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs during Cutting Edge. BUSHWALK can embed into the legitimate querymanifest.cgi file on compromised Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs. BUSHWALK can Base64 decode and RC4 decrypt malicious payloads sent through a web requests command parameter. BUSHWALK can write malicious payloads sent through a web requests command parameter. BUSHWALK can encrypt the resulting data generated from C2 commands with RC4. BUSHWALK is a web shell that has the ability to execute arbitrary commands or write files. BUSHWALK can modify the DSUserAgentCap.pm Perl module on Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs and either activate or deactivate depending on the value of the user agent in incoming HTTP requests.  **List of All Step-by-step mapping of the described behaviors to MITRE Enterprise techniques:

1. inserted into the legitimate querymanifest.cgi file on compromised Ivanti Connect Secure VPNs  
    The attacker places a web shell inside an existing web-application file.  
    T1505.003 (Server Software Component: Web Shell)  main technique T1505.

2. can Base64 decode and RC4 decrypt malicious payloads sent through a web requests command parameter.  
    Incoming C2 traffic is obfuscated/encoded and must be decoded before use.  
    T1132.001 (Data Encoding: Standard Encoding)  main technique T1132.

3. can write malicious payloads sent through a web requests command parameter.  
    The web shell writes attacker-supplied files to disk.  
    T1105 (Ingress Tool Transfer).

4. can encrypt the resulting data generated from C2 commands with RC4.  
    Outbound C2 traffic is encrypted to hide its contents.  
    T1573 (Encrypted Channel).

5. has the ability to execute arbitrary commands  
    The web shell provides a command-and-scripting interpreter interface.  
    T1059.004 (Command and Scripting Interpreter: Unix Shell)  main technique T1059.

6. can modify the DSUserAgentCap.pm Perl module depending on the value of the user agent in incoming HTTP requests.  
    The malware alters a legitimate system file to change its behavior based on request attributes, effectively masquerading or hiding its presence.  
    T1036.005 (Masquerading: Match Legitimate Name or Location)  main technique T1036.

Main technique IDs only (no sub-techniques):

1505,1132,1105,1573,1059,1036

samples.input: Extract all MITRE Enterprise attack patterns from the following text and map them to their corresponding MITRE technique IDs. Provide reasoning for each identification. Ensure the final line contains only the IDs for the main techniques, separated by commas, excluding any subtechnique IDs. MITRE Enterprise IDs are given below as reference.  **Text:** Akira ransomware, written in C++, is most prominently (but not exclusively) associated with the a ransomware-as-a-service entity Akira. Akira will execute PowerShell commands to delete system volume shadow copies. Akira executes from the Windows command line and can take various arguments for execution. Akira encrypts victim filesystems for financial extortion purposes. Akira examines files prior to encryption to determine if they meet requirements for encryption and can be encrypted by the ransomware. These checks are performed through native Windows functions such as GetFileAttributesW. Akira will delete system volume shadow copies via PowerShell commands. Akira executes native Windows functions such as GetFileAttributesW and GetSystemInfo. Akira can identify remote file shares for encryption. Akira verifies the deletion of volume shadow copies by checking for the existence of the process ID related to the process created to delete these items. Akira uses the GetSystemInfo Windows function to determine the number of processors on a victim machine. Akira will leverage COM objects accessed through WMI during execution to evade detection.   **List of All MITRE Enterprise technique IDs** ID    : Name T1548 : Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism T1134 messages.content: Extract all MITRE Enterprise attack patterns from the following text and map them to their corresponding MITRE technique IDs. Provide reasoning for each identification. Ensure the final line contains only the IDs for the main techniques, separated by commas, excluding any subtechnique IDs. MITRE Enterprise IDs are given below as reference.  **Text:** Akira ransomware, written in C++, is most prominently (but not exclusively) associated with the a ransomware-as-a-service entity Akira. Akira will execute PowerShell commands to delete system volume shadow copies. Akira executes from the Windows command line and can take various arguments for execution. Akira encrypts victim filesystems for financial extortion purposes. Akira examines files prior to encryption to determine if they meet requirements for encryption and can be encrypted by the ransomware. These checks are performed through native Windows functions such as GetFileAttributesW. Akira will delete system volume shadow copies via PowerShell commands. Akira executes native Windows functions such as GetFileAttributesW and GetSystemInfo. Akira can identify remote file shares for encryption. Akira verifies the deletion of volume shadow copies by checking for the existence of the process ID related to the process created to delete these items. Akira uses the GetSystemInfo Windows function to determine the number of processors on a victim machine. Akira will leverage COM objects accessed through WMI during execution to evade detection.   **List of All MITRE Enterprise technique IDs** ID    : Name T1548 : Abuse Elevation Control Mechanism T1134 Here is the step-by-step mapping of every relevant behavior described in the text to the corresponding MITRE Enterprise technique ID, followed by the final comma-separated list of main technique IDs.

1. Akira will execute PowerShell commands to delete system volume shadow copies.  
    Deleting shadow copies is a classic way to inhibit system recovery.  
   Technique: **T1490 Inhibit System Recovery**

2. Akira executes from the Windows command line and can take various arguments for execution.  
    Running commands via cmd.exe falls under the Windows Command Shell.  
   Technique: **T1059.003 Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell**  
   (Main technique: **T1059**)

3. Akira encrypts victim filesystems for financial extortion purposes.  
    Encrypting data to extort the victim is Data Encrypted for Impact.  
   Technique: **T1486 Data Encrypted for Impact**

4. Akira examines files prior to encryption  through native Windows functions such as GetFileAttributesW.  
    Enumerating files/directories and their attributes is File and Directory Discovery.  
   Technique: **T1083 File and Directory Discovery**

5. Akira will delete system volume shadow copies via PowerShell commands. (re-stated)  
    Same as #1; already counted.

6. Akira executes native Windows functions such as GetFileAttributesW and GetSystemInfo.  
    Using Windows API calls like GetSystemInfo is Native API usage.  
   Technique: **T1106 Native API**

7. Akira can identify remote file shares for encryption.  
    Discovering network shares is Network Share Discovery.  
   Technique: **T1135 Network Share Discovery**

8. Akira verifies the deletion of volume shadow copies by checking for the existence of the process ID   
    Enumerating running processes to confirm an action is Process Discovery.  
   Technique: **T1057 Process Discovery**

9. Akira uses the GetSystemInfo Windows function to determine the number of processors on a victim machine.  
    Gathering system information such as CPU count is System Information Discovery.  
   Technique: **T1082 System Information Discovery**

10. Akira will leverage COM objects accessed through WMI during execution to evade detection.  
     Using WMI (Windows Management Instrumentation) for execution is a distinct technique.  
    Technique: **T1047 Windows Management Instrumentation**

Summary of main technique IDs (excluding sub-techniques):

T1490,T1059,T1486,T1083,T1106,T1135,T1057,T1082,T1047

attachments.7f44e2d768adadb2a92f2b6c4e454901: Akira ransomware, written in C++, is most prominently (but not exclusively) associated with the a ransomware-as-a-service entity Akira. Akira will execute PowerShell commands to delete system volume shadow copies. Akira executes from the Windows command line and can take various arguments for execution. Akira encrypts victim filesystems for financial extortion purposes. Akira examines files prior to encryption to determine if they meet requirements for encryption and can be encrypted by the ransomware. These checks are performed through native Windows functions such as GetFileAttributesW. Akira will delete system volume shadow copies via PowerShell commands. Akira executes native Windows functions such as GetFileAttributesW and GetSystemInfo. Akira can identify remote file shares for encryption. Akira verifies the deletion of volume shadow copies by checking for the existence of the process ID related to the process created to delete these items. Akira uses the GetSystemInfo Windows function to determine the number of processors on a victim machine. Akira will leverage COM objects accessed through WMI during execution to evade detection.
attachments.c43cdf60baa7887d7be0e369be6b8f30:
Here is the step-by-step mapping of every relevant behavior described in the text to the corresponding MITRE Enterprise technique ID, followed by the final comma-separated list of main technique IDs.

1. Akira will execute PowerShell commands to delete system volume shadow copies.  
    Deleting shadow copies is a classic way to inhibit system recovery.  
   Technique: **T1490 Inhibit System Recovery**

2. Akira executes from the Windows command line and can take various arguments for execution.  
    Running commands via cmd.exe falls under the Windows Command Shell.  
   Technique: **T1059.003 Command and Scripting Interpreter: Windows Command Shell**  
   (Main technique: **T1059**)

3. Akira encrypts victim filesystems for financial extortion purposes.  
    Encrypting data to extort the victim is Data Encrypted for Impact.  
   Technique: **T1486 Data Encrypted for Impact**

4. Akira examines files prior to encryption  through native Windows functions such as GetFileAttributesW.  
    Enumerating files/directories and their attributes is File and Directory Discovery.  
   Technique: **T1083 File and Directory Discovery**

5. Akira will delete system volume shadow copies via PowerShell commands. (re-stated)  
    Same as #1; already counted.

6. Akira executes native Windows functions such as GetFileAttributesW and GetSystemInfo.  
    Using Windows API calls like GetSystemInfo is Native API usage.  
   Technique: **T1106 Native API**

7. Akira can identify remote file shares for encryption.  
    Discovering network shares is Network Share Discovery.  
   Technique: **T1135 Network Share Discovery**

8. Akira verifies the deletion of volume shadow copies by checking for the existence of the process ID   
    Enumerating running processes to confirm an action is Process Discovery.  
   Technique: **T1057 Process Discovery**

9. Akira uses the GetSystemInfo Windows function to determine the number of processors on a victim machine.  
    Gathering system information such as CPU count is System Information Discovery.  
   Technique: **T1082 System Information Discovery**

10. Akira will leverage COM objects accessed through WMI during execution to evade detection.  
     Using WMI (Windows Management Instrumentation) for execution is a distinct technique.  
    Technique: **T1047 Windows Management Instrumentation**

Summary of main technique IDs (excluding sub-techniques):

T1490,T1059,T1486,T1083,T1106,T1135,T1057,T1082,T1047

Step-by-step mapping of the described behaviors to MITRE Enterprise techniques.

1. initially installed and executed through an initial shell script  
    A shell script is executed by the user or another process to drop/run the malware.  
    T1204 User Execution.

2. NKAbuse uses a Cron job to establish persistence when infecting Linux hosts.  
    Cron is a Linux job scheduler used to keep the malware running.  
    T1053 Scheduled Task/Job.

3. NKAbuse will check victim systems to ensure only one copy of the malware is running.  
    The malware inspects running processes to see if another instance exists.  
    T1057 Process Discovery.

4. NKAbuse has abused the NKN public blockchain protocol for its C2 communications.  
    NKN is an application-layer protocol used for command-and-control traffic.  
    T1071 Application Layer Protocol.

5. NKAbuse can take screenshots of the victim machine.  
    Capturing the screen is a form of screen capture.  
    T1113 Screen Capture.

6. NKAbuse conducts multiple system checks and includes these in subsequent heartbeat messages to the malware's command and control server.  
    Collecting system information and sending it to C2 is system information discovery plus C2 heartbeat.  
    T1082 System Information Discovery (discovery aspect) and T1041 Exfiltration Over C2 Channel (reporting aspect).  
   (We list both.)

7. NKAbuse utilizes external services such as ifconfig.me to identify the victim machine's IP address.  
    Querying an external service to learn the victims public IP is system network configuration discovery.  
    T1016 System Network Configuration Discovery.

8. NKAbuse enables multiple types of network denial of service capabilities across several protocols post-installation.  
    Actively performing DoS attacks.  
    T1498 Network Denial of Service.

9. functioning as a potent implant (implies the malware is transferred onto the host).  
    Transferring the implant file to the target.  
    T1105 Ingress Tool Transfer.

Main technique IDs only (no sub-techniques):

T1204,T1053,T1057,T1071,T1113,T1082,T1041,T1016,T1498,T1105

1. initially installed and executed through an initial shell script  
    A shell script is executed by the user or another process to drop/run the malware.  
    T1204 User Execution.

2. NKAbuse uses a Cron job to establish persistence when infecting Linux hosts.  
    Cron is a Linux job scheduler used to keep the malware running.  
    T1053 Scheduled Task/Job.

3. NKAbuse will check victim systems to ensure only one copy of the malware is running.  
    The malware inspects running processes to see if another instance exists.  
    T1057 Process Discovery.

4. NKAbuse has abused the NKN public blockchain protocol for its C2 communications.  
    NKN is an application-layer protocol used for command-and-control traffic.  
    T1071 Application Layer Protocol.

5. NKAbuse can take screenshots of the victim machine.  
    Capturing the screen is a form of screen capture.  
    T1113 Screen Capture.

6. NKAbuse conducts multiple system checks and includes these in subsequent heartbeat messages to the malware's command and control server.  
    Collecting system information and sending it to C2 is system information discovery plus C2 heartbeat.  
    T1082 System Information Discovery (discovery aspect) and T1041 Exfiltration Over C2 Channel (reporting aspect).  
   (We list both.)

7. NKAbuse utilizes external services such as ifconfig.me to identify the victim machine's IP address.  
    Querying an external service to learn the victims public IP is system network configuration discovery.  
    T1016 System Network Configuration Discovery.

8. NKAbuse enables multiple types of network denial of service capabilities across several protocols post-installation.  
    Actively performing DoS attacks.  
    T1498 Network Denial of Service.

9. functioning as a potent implant (implies the malware is transferred onto the host).  
    Transferring the implant file to the target.  
    T1105 Ingress Tool Transfer.

Main technique IDs only (no sub-techniques):

T1204,T1053,T1057,T1071,T1113,T1082,T1041,T1016,T1498,T1105

samples.input: Extract all MITRE Enterprise attack patterns from the following text and map them to their corresponding MITRE technique IDs. Provide reasoning for each identification. Ensure the final line contains only the IDs for the main techniques, separated by commas, excluding any subtechnique IDs. MITRE Enterprise IDs are given below as reference.  **Text:** SLOWPULSE is a malware that was used by APT5 as early as 2020 including against U.S. Defense Industrial Base (DIB) companies. SLOWPULSE has several variants and can modify legitimate Pulse Secure VPN files in order to log credentials and bypass single and two-factor authentication flows. SLOWPULSE is applied in compromised environments through modifications to legitimate Pulse Secure files. SLOWPULSE can write logged ACE credentials to /home/perl/PAUS.pm in append mode, using the format string %s:%s\n. SLOWPULSE can modify LDAP and two factor authentication flows by inspecting login credentials and forcing successful authentication if the provided password matches a chosen backdoor password. SLOWPULSE can insert malicious logic to bypass RADIUS and ACE two factor authentication (2FA) flows if a designated attacker-supplied password is provided. SLOWPULSE can log credentials on compromised Pulse Secure VPNs during the DSAuth::AceAuthServer::checkUsernamePasswordACE-2FA authentication procedure. SLOWPULSE can hide malicious code in the padding regions between legitimate functions in the Pulse Secure libdsplibs.so file.  **List of All MITRE Enterprise technique IDs** ID    : Name T1548 : Abuse 1. modify legitimate Pulse Secure VPN files  to log credentials  
    This is tampering with a legitimate software binary to add malicious functionality.  
    T1554  Compromise Host Software Binary

2. bypass single and two-factor authentication flows  by inspecting login credentials and forcing successful authentication if the provided password matches a chosen backdoor password  
    Altering the authentication process itself to accept an attacker-chosen password.  
    T1556  Modify Authentication Process

3. insert malicious logic to bypass RADIUS and ACE two-factor authentication (2FA) flows  
    Same underlying behavior as above: modifying the authentication mechanism.  
    T1556  Modify Authentication Process (already counted)

4. log credentials on compromised Pulse Secure VPNs during the  authentication procedure  
    Capturing user credentials as they are entered.  
    T1056  Input Capture

5. hide malicious code in the padding regions between legitimate functions in the Pulse Secure libdsplibs.so file  
    Concealing malicious artifacts within a binary.  
    T1564  Hide Artifacts

These five distinct techniques cover every described capability.

T1554,T1556,T1056,T1564

metadata.description: SLOWPULSE is a malware that was used by APT5 as early as 2020 including against U.S. Defense Industrial Base (DIB) companies. SLOWPULSE has several variants and can modify legitimate Pulse Secure VPN files in order to log credentials and bypass single and two-factor authentication flows. SLOWPULSE is applied in compromised environments through modifications to legitimate Pulse Secure files. SLOWPULSE can write logged ACE credentials to /home/perl/PAUS.pm in append mode, using the format string %s:%s\n. SLOWPULSE can modify LDAP and two factor authentication flows by inspecting login credentials and forcing successful authentication if the provided password matches a chosen backdoor password. SLOWPULSE can insert malicious logic to bypass RADIUS and ACE two factor authentication (2FA) flows if a designated attacker-supplied password is provided. SLOWPULSE can log credentials on compromised Pulse Secure VPNs during the DSAuth::AceAuthServer::checkUsernamePasswordACE-2FA authentication procedure. SLOWPULSE can hide malicious code in the padding regions between legitimate functions in the Pulse Secure libdsplibs.so file.

samples.input: Extract all MITRE Enterprise attack patterns from the following text and map them to their corresponding MITRE technique IDs. Provide reasoning for each identification. Ensure the final line contains only the IDs for the main techniques, separated by commas, excluding any subtechnique IDs. MITRE Enterprise IDs are given below as reference.  **Text:** RAPIDPULSE is a web shell that exists as a modification to a legitimate Pulse Secure file that has been used by APT5 since at least 2021. RAPIDPULSE retrieves files from the victim system via encrypted commands sent to the web shell. RAPIDPULSE listens for specific HTTP query parameters in received communications. If specific parameters match, a hard-coded RC4 key is used to decrypt the HTTP query paremter hmacTime. This decrypts to a filename that is then open, read, encrypted with the same RC4 key, base64-encoded, written to standard out, then passed as a response to the HTTP request. RAPIDPULSE has the ability to RC4 encrypt and base64 encode decrypted files on compromised servers prior to writing them to stdout. RAPIDPULSE is a web shell that is capable of arbitrary file read on targeted web servers to exfiltrate items of interest on the victim device.[1]  **List of All MITRE Enterprise technique IDs** ID messages.content: Extract all MITRE Enterprise attack patterns from the following text and map them to their corresponding MITRE technique IDs. Provide reasoning for each identification. Ensure the final line contains only the IDs for the main techniques, separated by commas, excluding any subtechnique IDs. MITRE Enterprise IDs are given below as reference.  **Text:** RAPIDPULSE is a web shell that exists as a modification to a legitimate Pulse Secure file that has been used by APT5 since at least 2021. RAPIDPULSE retrieves files from the victim system via encrypted commands sent to the web shell. RAPIDPULSE listens for specific HTTP query parameters in received communications. If specific parameters match, a hard-coded RC4 key is used to decrypt the HTTP query paremter hmacTime. This decrypts to a filename that is then open, read, encrypted with the same RC4 key, base64-encoded, written to standard out, then passed as a response to the HTTP request. RAPIDPULSE has the ability to RC4 encrypt and base64 encode decrypted files on compromised servers prior to writing them to stdout. RAPIDPULSE is a web shell that is capable of arbitrary file read on targeted web servers to exfiltrate items of interest on the victim device.[1]  **List of All MITRE Enterprise technique IDs** ID Identified techniques and reasoning:

1. T1505  Server Software Component  
   Reasoning: RAPIDPULSE is explicitly described as a web shell that exists as a modification to a legitimate Pulse Secure file, i.e., a malicious component added to existing server software.

2. T1059  Command and Scripting Interpreter  
   Reasoning: Web shells typically accept and execute commands or scripts sent by the attacker; the text notes the shell retrieves files  via encrypted commands, indicating command/script execution.

3. T1071  Application Layer Protocol  
   Reasoning: The shell listens for specific HTTP query parameters and responds over HTTP, using an application-layer protocol for C2.

4. T1027  Obfuscated Files or Information  
   Reasoning: Data is RC4-encrypted and base64-encoded before exfiltration, clearly obfuscating the content.

5. T1041  Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
   Reasoning: The encrypted file content is written to standard out, then passed as a response to the HTTP request, i.e., exfiltrated back over the same C2 channel.

6. T1005  Data from Local System  
   Reasoning: The shell has the ability  to exfiltrate items of interest on the victim device, i.e., collect data from the local system.

Final technique IDs (main techniques only, no sub-techniques):

T1505,T1059,T1071,T1027,T1041,T1005

Identified techniques and reasoning

1. T1505.003  Server Software Component: Web Shell  
   PULSECHECK is explicitly described as a web shell written in Perl that is installed on the victim web server to enable remote access and command execution.

2. T1059.004  Command and Scripting Interpreter: Unix Shell  
   The text states the shell can use Unix shell script for command execution, matching the Unix Shell sub-technique.

3. T1132.001  Data Encoding: Standard Encoding  
   C2 traffic is base-64 encode[d], a standard encoding scheme used to obfuscate data in transit.

4. T1041  Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
   The base-64-encoded data is sent through C2, i.e., the same channel used for control, satisfying the definition of exfiltration over the C2 channel.

5. T1071.001  Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols  
   The implant checks HTTP request headers and returns output in an HTTP header, confirming use of web-based application-layer protocols for C2.

Main (non-sub) technique IDs only: T1505,T1059,T1132,T1041,T1071

attachments.e8f44b230585b80c13d358023eb02f4e: PULSECHECK is a web shell written in Perl that was used by APT5 as early as 2020 including against Pulse Secure VPNs at US Defense Industrial Base (DIB) companies. PULSECHECK can check HTTP request headers for a specific backdoor key and if found will output the result of the command in the variable HTTP_X_CMD. PULSECHECK can use Unix shell script for command execution. PULSECHECK can base-64 encode encrypted data sent through C2. PULSECHECK is a web shell that can enable command execution on compromised servers.
attachments.817fc7d657806523cc63ef4464a96683:
Identified techniques and reasoning

1. T1505.003  Server Software Component: Web Shell  
   PULSECHECK is explicitly described as a web shell written in Perl that is installed on the victim web server to enable remote access and command execution.

2. T1059.004  Command and Scripting Interpreter: Unix Shell  
   The text states the shell can use Unix shell script for command execution, matching the Unix Shell sub-technique.

3. T1132.001  Data Encoding: Standard Encoding  
   C2 traffic is base-64 encode[d], a standard encoding scheme used to obfuscate data in transit.

4. T1041  Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
   The base-64-encoded data is sent through C2, i.e., the same channel used for control, satisfying the definition of exfiltration over the C2 channel.

5. T1071.001  Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols  
   The implant checks HTTP request headers and returns output in an HTTP header, confirming use of web-based application-layer protocols for C2.

Main (non-sub) technique IDs only: T1505,T1059,T1132,T1041,T1071

Here is the step-by-step mapping of every described capability to the corresponding MITRE Mobile ATT&CK technique, followed by the final comma-separated list of main technique IDs.

1. Phenakite can record phone calls.  
    T1616  Call Control (directly matches the ability to record or otherwise control phone calls).

2. Phenakite can collect and exfiltrate WhatsApp media, photos and files with specific extensions, such as .pdf and .doc.  
    T1533  Data from Local System (collecting arbitrary user files from the device).

3. Phenakite has included exploits for jailbreaking infected devices.  
    T1404  Exploitation for Privilege Escalation (jailbreaking is a classic iOS privilege-escalation exploit).

4. Phenakite can download additional malware to the victim device.  
    T1407  Download New Code at Runtime (downloading and executing new payloads at runtime).

5. Phenakite has used phishing sites for iCloud and Facebook   
    T1660  Phishing (creation/use of phishing pages to harvest credentials).

6. Phenakite can masquerade as the chat application Magic Smile.  
    T1655  Masquerading (pretending to be a legitimate app to deceive the user).

7. Phenakite can exfiltrate the victim devices contact list.  
    T1636  Protected User Data (contacts are protected user data on iOS).

8. Phenakite can read SMS messages.  
    T1582  SMS Control (reading/intercepting SMS messages).

9. Phenakite can collect device metadata.  
    T1426  System Information Discovery (gathering device/OS metadata).

10. Phenakite can capture pictures and videos.  
     T1513  Screen Capture (for screen-based capture) and T1512  Video Capture (for camera-based capture).  
    Since the text explicitly mentions both pictures and videos, both techniques apply.

Final list of main technique IDs (no sub-techniques):

T1616,T1533,T1404,T1407,T1660,T1655,T1636,T1582,T1426,T1513,T1512

Ensure the final line contains only the IDs for the main techniques, separated by commas, excluding any subtechnique IDs. Identified techniques and reasoning:

1. T1505  Server Software Component  
   Reasoning: RAPIDPULSE is explicitly described as a web shell that exists as a modification to a legitimate Pulse Secure file, i.e., a malicious component added to existing server software.

2. T1059  Command and Scripting Interpreter  
   Reasoning: Web shells typically accept and execute commands or scripts sent by the attacker; the text notes the shell retrieves files  via encrypted commands, indicating command/script execution.

3. T1071  Application Layer Protocol  
   Reasoning: The shell listens for specific HTTP query parameters and responds over HTTP, using an application-layer protocol for C2.

4. T1027  Obfuscated Files or Information  
   Reasoning: Data is RC4-encrypted and base64-encoded before exfiltration, clearly obfuscating the content.

5. T1041  Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
   Reasoning: The encrypted file content is written to standard out, then passed as a response to the HTTP request, i.e., exfiltrated back over the same C2 channel.

6. T1005  Data from Local System  
   Reasoning: The shell has the ability  to exfiltrate items of interest on the victim device, i.e., collect data from the local system.

Final technique IDs (main techniques only, no sub-techniques):

T1505,T1059,T1071,T1027,T1041,T1005

Identified techniques and reasoning

1. T1505.003  Server Software Component: Web Shell  
   PULSECHECK is explicitly described as a web shell written in Perl that is installed on the victim web server to enable remote access and command execution.

2. T1059.004  Command and Scripting Interpreter: Unix Shell  
   The text states the shell can use Unix shell script for command execution, matching the Unix Shell sub-technique.

3. T1132.001  Data Encoding: Standard Encoding  
   C2 traffic is base-64 encode[d], a standard encoding scheme used to obfuscate data in transit.

4. T1041  Exfiltration Over C2 Channel  
   The base-64-encoded data is sent through C2, i.e., the same channel used for control, satisfying the definition of exfiltration over the C2 channel.

5. T1071.001  Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols  
   The implant checks HTTP request headers and returns output in an HTTP header, confirming use of web-based application-layer protocols for C2.
